text:
Quick debate if you will, which would you prefer to use when building a dependency graph with Dagger 2?
`@Inject` annotation on constructors or `@Provides` even when its a simple binding (non-3rd-party, concrete implementation)
I prefer @Inject
: sigh : `afterEvaluate` is not called if applied in `allprojects`
they could at least throw a warning or something

>In these cases, you should just postpone the change using a Handler or a similar mechanism.

<http://documention.android.com/random-hacks-you-gotta-do|documention.android.com/random-hacks-you-gotta-do>

<https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/build_lifecycle.html#build_lifecycle_events>

wtf.. it should work lol
it’s basically in the sample
what u doing?
applying a plugin to projects in the allprojects dsl
that plugin applies an afterEvaluate to the project which calls a method that has a lot of unit testing so I know the method works so maybe apply interferes somehow
need help guys
I need to make 100 network requests in blocks of 5 parallel per time
with rxJava
like 5 parallel running and when they all complete 5 more running
until all done
:thinking_face:
just use an executor
you can limit it to 5 threads
wat. why.
Don’t get it
all 100 of them are in the same chain?
:thinking_face:
like you get 5 at a time?

but not sequentially\
and not all at the same time
should be smth like a buffer
to execute 5-10 at a time
use an executor and Schedulers.from

<@U3UFN8Z0D|mmurph> has joined the channel

Anyone have experience using TaskStackBuilder? I’m opening up a NotificationDetailActivity when a notification is clicked. I’m using a new pendingintent to open the activity from a fcm notification; I am not using TaskStackBuilder.getPendingIntent() because it’s very broken. Anyway; my onBackPressed() method is checking to see if notification was pressed when app was closed with if(isTaskRoot). If so, it does TSB.addNextIntentWithParentStack(NotifListActivity) but when the ListActivity is run it no longer opens NotificationDetails when notifications are pressed. It’s a very strange issue and I can’t seem to figure out what is wrong with TaskStackBuilder
Here is the code that is producing the bug: <http://pastebin.com/6zQCTDbH>
NotificationListActivity has launchMode = singleTask and NotificationDetailActivity is singleTop.
<@U3TNY68C8|bryadd> has joined the channel

Hey all - I'm working with a friend on a project that they are kind of stumped with. Thought I'd ask the community here for ideas. The quick version is that we are trying to use a touchscreen monitor with an iStick A300 android device. It seems that the iStick manufacturer has removed or not added touchscreen capability from the iStick. 
Ideally we would find a way to add that functionality back into the android OS. Any idea what we could do?
Generally that includes compiling a new kernel and flashing that onto the device, then providing the userland access to it somehow
Hmmmm ok. If I'm trying to find someone who knows how to do that, do you know what type of skills I would search for?
<@U3JKA9A77> The issue was one of the elements were being set to a height of 0 in the css
<@U3TNY68C8> you could try looking around in the yocto project repos. They might have a build for that device
ok thanks <@U3UA52NR1> , I'll check it out
If anyone thinks they could help out with this project by the way then PM me. They are kind of in a bind right now and and would be happy to have a quick contract job for this
Mmm cortex-a9 processor.. Very tempting
Any1 using RxBindings in a RecyclerView 4 clicks?

<@U3TNY68C8> not a lot of people here really focus on that in particular. It's also not one of the easiest jobs and if you're prepared to pay someone for, it's probably cheaper to just buy something better.
<@U39P7U6EP> I still dont understand how Flow is working, you are saving layout ID's, how are you instantiating the View class
<@U3E2EEX38> by inflating the layout
The custom viewgroup is the root of the layout xml, so it gets inflated by the inflater from the layout id
ye sure, but how do you then do anything with the viewGroup
you won't be able to access it
It would be just an inflated layout
What do you mean "do anything"
When I inflated a layout with a custom viewGroup I couldnot get a ref to the Custom viewgroup
You do ButterKnife.bind in onFinishInflate
The custom viewgroup handles itself
I did
Its just  view
say you have MyCustomeView
Yes
if you just infalte the layout R.layout.custom_view
you can't actually get to the instance of MyCustomView
only the layout
since you never created an actual instance
What? They are the same thing
no
The inflater creates the custom viewgroup
What you get is the custom viewgroup
yes, but lets say you want to access a memeber variable on the custom viewgroup, how do you do that with out an instance?
Just make sure the custom viewgroup is the root view in the layout
I did
it doesnt work
I do not see why you would want to do that
I have made 3 view based projects and I never needed accessing internal variables.
I send parameters and communicate via scoped presenter
But you can still check against custom viewgroup as `instanceof` lol
The inflated view *is* the custom viewgroup
ye I get that
but its just the view
What do you mean "that's just the view"
That's the custom view, that's the point
Yes, but you do not actually have a handle to the CustomClass
i wanted to pass data on creation
when its inflated
Have you read the second article
You can send params with context wrapper
hmmm
I'm pretty sure I linked it
This is what part 2 is about and I actually finished writing that lol
ye I read it, it still didn't explain, i'll read it again.
It does
How are you passing data to view
liek that
I pass ID in the key
The key is shared via context wrapper
You can get the key as `KeyContextWrapper.getKey()`
key is the layout ID?
or customVIewGroup
It really just doesn't make any sense to me
I don't understand how you can pass data bewtween views
The parcelable that describe the current application state
It can contain data like IDs
oh right
And any parcelable
I'd love to call it State but that's what I named the view state storage
ye the name was confusing me
i get it now
I know
I don't really like the name `Key` either
I could rename `Key` to `AppState`, and `State` to `ViewState`
ye that would be more logical
That'd be more descriptive I guess
My naming convention was from Flow in this regard
yes
Key is a strange name
lol
ye key to me is like the ID
its the same thing
Well yeah but it also has the ID
So that's how it works
ye it makes sense now
ContextWrapper is such a cool trick
you dont ever need to have a ref to the view
ye I never knew it

 * Proxying implementation of Context that simply delegates all of its calls to
 * another Context.  Can be subclassed to modify behavior without changing
 * the original Context.

text: tell me again why you are using contextWrapper to access the activity?
like
whats the difference between that and just calling the activity
or injecting it
oh i see
I am reading
so the backstack is now like a service
Is it a good idea to let Presenters or other classes  access the back stack?
I would have thought not
presenters aren't supposed to know about android at all
The backstack becomes separate from Android
Apart from that whatever you put into it extends Parcelable
The presenter should handle navigation if the backstack is separate from Android, imo
I'd inject it from dagger
Into the presenter
hmm
oh you mean as in navigating views?
like if I am in Login and I want to navigate to main, logins presenter can call Goto on the backstack
is that what you mean?
well yes, my presenter makes the original call to switch views
it goes down the chain
you are just bypassing all that with your contextWrapper
its pretty nice
Was that the source of any bugs in the original flow?
How do you handle Intents

> like if I am in Login and I want to navigate to main, logins presenter can call Goto on the backstack

yes that's what I mean
your navigation becomes detached from the android framework which is nice

<@U3E2EEX38> > Was that the source of any bugs in the original flow?

no, context wrappers work fine, it had a bug a long time ago but it was actually a bug in support library and has been fixed since
intent handling is odd in the original Flow, you can add a history to an intent, which Flow can load with `onNewIntent()` which replaces current history in the stack
it is actually completely bugged in Flow by default
but technically i think you could handle different schemes in your one activity, and handle each of them accordingly
i have not had to work with "defining multiple intent filters" though and then deep linking into the app
all i ever had to do was start the app at a given place with a pending intent, that was fairly trivial (after fixing the intent handling in flow, anyways)
I use TaskStackBuilder for back stack navigation
It’s a nightmare
<@U3UA52NR1> that's why I don't use this stuff :smile:

<@U39P7U6EP> it’s only a nightmare because it doesn’t work like it’s suppose to lol I don’t have experience using NavUtils or Flow but I can’t imagine they work well and keep activities from being recreated. Which is pretty important for what I’m trying to do

<@U3UA52NR1>  > but I can’t imagine they work well and keep activities from being recreated. 

what

<@U39P7U6EP> I was trying to open an activity from a notification, and make sure it had the right back stack. But because we don’t persist the information from the notification, if the parent activity was destroyed, it would not call the onRestoreInstanceState and the parent activity data was lost.
<@U39P7U6EP> I haven’t used other libraries so idk if they recreate the activity or not. I’m also not sure when the instanceState is actually saved.
<@U3UA52NR1> ah that's an interesting story, technically with Flow I could make sure the info exists, *but* only if i didn't restore the notification after a force stop
force stop removes alarm manager registrations and that's kind of a pain
because i lost my view state with the force stop, so i was forced to recreate it with no state after a force stop
lol saving instance states seems to be very unreliable. Which is incredibly annoying
i only had trouble after force stop
I guess it doesn’t saveInstanceState when it is force closed, but for me it saves it and doesn’t restore
force stop clears literally everything
including the alarm manager pending intent
it's really annoying to work against
lol I mean that makes sense
It generally shouldn’t force stop in production. Even then saving an alarm and timestamp to SharedPreferences is no biggie
well yes, but you have to add it back on start-up :smile:
that part is annoying
it's true btw, NavUtils is a pain
it recreated the previous activity when you presssed "up"

lol good thing I decided not to use it. Someone on the androiddev irc channel was telling me to use NavUtils. Literally the only issue on github for the version I just pushed to the play store is the scenario where the activity was forced to get recreated :laughing: I was considering using flow or NavUtils but I like to understand how it works.
Flow is also buggy out of the box, I use my own fork
works for me

Using android stuff isn’t that bad really. There’s really not a whole lot of boilerplate for it. Understanding why Android is adding all these weird options is a pain. Or why certain method calls do weird things I don’t want it to. Like onNextIntent uses Intent.FLAG_ACTIVITY_ something I can’t remember. When I specifically didn’t want it to. But many of the issues I’m running in to could be fixed for the android source. Fixing issues for a dependency that I don’t even really need sounds like much more of a hassle in the long run
This post is worth a read lol <https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33943588/android-singletask-activity-not-as-the-root/33944303>
